This course advanced my proficiency in the Chinese language beyond anything that I had expected at the onset of the semester. I amassed information regarding the sentence structures and types, vocabulary, idiomatic phrases, and pronunciation that encompasses Mandarin Chinese. Initially, the grammatical structure of Chinese sentences was a little bit difficult to master as the placement of time phrases differs drastically from English. In Mandarin, the time phrase is placed in the beginning of the sentence, before the verb, as to contextualize the time tense of the sentence. However, as I practiced the sentence structure more often and perfected establishing the tense of the sentence at the beginning, I began to improve my speech. Additionally, I learned methods to understand and write Chinese characters efficiently. One extremely helpful method was to connect the meaning of the character in some way to its structure. For instance, for the character, "Shangwang," which means to "surf the internet," I found that part of the character looked like a fish net. This helped me to remember not just the meaning of the character but how to write it as well. As I became more versed in writing character I also began to see how different characters were composed of similar parts, which allowed me to further connect vocabulary words to one another and remember them more easily. My pronunciation of Chinese tones also improved tremendously, especially my pronunciation of words with different tones. One of the most useful insights that I developed during this course was in how to tailor my response to questions that I was asked. initially, I found it somewhat difficult to respond quickly to simple questions that I was asked in Chinese, because I would spend time searching through the multiple answers that I could respond with and constantly revise my response as I spoke it. Through the instruction of Shen Laoshi, I learned how to use the structure of the question I was asked to respond to someone's inquiry. This helped me increasingly respond completely and succinctly to questions I was asked.

The underlying strength of this course lies in its constant testing structure. The presence of daily quizzes not only served as a strong incentive to study the language , but also held me accountable. As a result my knowledge of vocabulary, grammatical structure, and characters increased rapidly. Another strength of the course was its interactive aspect. After learning or reviewing a grammar rule or concept we would practice using those rules in sentences in order to solidify our understanding of the concept as well as increase our flexibility of speech. I think a weakness of this course is its lack of emphasis on methods that can be used to recognize and remember how to write characters. I think that further exploration into this aspect of learning Chinese would make a huge impact in the advancement of students in their studies.

I would without a doubt recommend this course to another student. For the student looking to learn how to speak Chinese at a conversational level, this course does much to prepare him or her how to adapt to different topics that they may encounter and provides a strong foundation for communicating questions, statements, and opinions. This course also helps to introduce students to the rich and vibrant aspects of Chinese culture and instills a deep interest in the customs and practices in China. At the least this course will help to expand your knowledge of different cultures around the world and will challenge you in new and exciting ways.
